meanings.definition: Extremely dirty and unpleasant, especially as a result of poverty or neglect.
meanings.sent1: The squalid alley was filled with trash and filth.
meanings.sent2: The abandoned house had a squalid interior with moldy walls.
meanings.sent3: Despite its squalid appearance, the old bookstore had a charm that drew customers.
meanings.sent4: The squalid conditions of the prison cell made it feel like a dungeon.
meanings.sent5: The squalid smell of the garbage dump lingered in the air.

meanings.definition: Showing or involving a contemptible lack of moral standards.
meanings.sent1: The squalid behavior of the corrupt politician shocked the public.
meanings.sent2: The squalid actions of the dishonest businessman were exposed in the news.
meanings.sent3: It was squalid of him to cheat on the exam when he knew it was wrong.
meanings.sent4: The squalid nature of the crime left a stain on the community.
meanings.sent5: Her squalid betrayal of her friend was unforgivable.
